slides.title: Introduction to Coverages in PolicyCenter
slides.notes: Kick off the discussion on coverages, an essential part of the PolicyCenter that developers interact with frequently.
slides.narration: Welcome to our deep dive into coverages within PolicyCenter. Coverages are central to any insurance policy and understanding their configuration and behavior is critical for developers. We'll explore how coverages are defined, managed, and customized in PolicyCenter, giving you practical insights into their implementation. Let's jump in and see how coverages are structured and how they integrate with other components of PolicyCenter.
slides.ocrText: Coverages

slides.title: Understanding Coverables and Coverages
slides.notes: Coverables are entities that can have coverage applied, such as properties or liabilities.
slides.narration: First, let's clarify the terms coverables and coverages. A coverable is essentially any entity that can be insured, like a house or a person in liability insurance. PolicyCenter uses the policy line as a coverable to represent insureds. For location-based coverages, you should create a specific coverable entity rather than using PolicyLocation directly. As developers, it's crucial to understand that each coverable is represented by its own entity within the data model.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

Define a coverage

Define a coverable

Describe a coverage category

Describe subclause relationships in Advanced
Product Designer

slides.title: Implementing Coverables in PolicyCenter
slides.originalNotes:
Coverables and coverages
The term coverable refers to any covered object. For example, insurance terminology refers to a covered object, such as a house, as a coverable.
For liability, the insured is the coverable.
For liability coverages, PolicyCenter designates the policy line as the coverable to represent the insured.
For coverages that attach at a location, the location is a coverable. Do not use PolicyLocation as the coverable, but instead, create a separate coverable entity.

Guidewire makes the policy line a coverable to represent the named insureds. Configuration users can further sub-divide coverables into Property coverables and Liability coverables. Property coverables are things with physical attributes (height, weight, value, construction type, age, and similar attributes, for example). Liability coverables are operations represented typically by class codes (coal mining, personal auto operation, for example).

Developers should know that each coverable is stored in its own entity.
slides.notes:
Coverables and coverages
The term coverable refers to any covered object. For example, insurance terminology refers to a covered object, such as a house, as a coverable.
For liability, the insured is the coverable.
For liability coverages, PolicyCenter designates the policy line as the coverable to represent the insured.
For coverages that attach at a location, the location is a coverable. Do not use PolicyLocation as the coverable, but instead, create a separate coverable entity.

Guidewire makes the policy line a coverable to represent the named insureds. Configuration users can further sub-divide coverables into Property coverables and Liability coverables. Property coverables are things with physical attributes (height, weight, value, construction type, age, and similar attributes, for example). Liability coverables are operations represented typically by class codes (coal mining, personal auto operation, for example).

Developers should know that each coverable is stored in its own entity.
slides.narration: Now, let's delve into the technical implementation of coverables. The Coverable entity implements the CoverableDelegate interface, which encapsulates the behavior and properties of a coverable. This abstraction allows for consistent handling of coverables across different parts of PolicyCenter. All configuration related to coverables happens at the coverage level, giving developers flexibility in how they manage and extend coverage behaviors.

| Coverables and coverages

slides.title: Defining Coverages in the Product Model
slides.originalNotes:
Coverages
There are important aspects of the coverable that are relevant to developers. They are:
1. The Coverable entity implements CoverableDelegate interface
2. A coverable delegate encapsulates coverage behavior
3. All other coverable-related configuration occurs at coverage level
slides.notes:
Coverages
There are important aspects of the coverable that are relevant to developers. They are:
1. The Coverable entity implements CoverableDelegate interface
2. A coverable delegate encapsulates coverage behavior
3. All other coverable-related configuration occurs at coverage level
slides.narration: Coverages are defined via coverage patterns within the product model. Each CoveragePattern specifies where the coverage attaches, its name, category, availability, and requiredness. These patterns are synchronized with the product model to ensure consistency across the system. Developers need to configure these patterns accurately to reflect the insurer's offerings and business rules effectively.
slides.ocrText:
| Coverages

* Coverages are attached to coverables

* Coverages are patterns in the product ty
model where each coverage pattern is
associated with a relevant entity

•« Examples of coverage include theft
coverage, fire coverage or liability vehicle
damage (on the policy line)

This coverable, the dwelling,
has fire coverage

slides.title: Attributes of Coverage Patterns
slides.originalNotes:
Defining coverages in the product model
The product model defines Coverage pattems. Each CoveragePattern defines the following, l)the Coverable where the coverage is attached 2) the coverage name (used in the IJI), 3) the Coverage Category (used for IJI grouping), 4) coverage availability, and 5) the coverage erequiredness" — whether it is required, suggested, or electable. The pattern also defines the coverage table where the coverage will be stored after it is created. These settings areenforced when the coverages are synchronized with the product model. There is one Coverage pattern for each coverage offered by the insurer.
slides.notes:
Defining coverages in the product model
The product model defines Coverage pattems. Each CoveragePattern defines the following, l)the Coverable where the coverage is attached 2) the coverage name (used in the IJI), 3) the Coverage Category (used for IJI grouping), 4) coverage availability, and 5) the coverage erequiredness" — whether it is required, suggested, or electable. The pattern also defines the coverage table where the coverage will be stored after it is created. These settings areenforced when the coverages are synchronized with the product model. There is one Coverage pattern for each coverage offered by the insurer.
slides.narration: The attributes within a CoveragePattern are pivotal as they dictate whether a coverage is offered, and if users can opt to include or exclude it from a policy. Typically, business analysts gather these requirements, and as developers, we implement them. This ensures that the system aligns with business needs while providing a robust framework for policy coverage management.
slides.ocrText:

coverage in an existing line of business (e.g.

slides.title: Associating Coverage Tables with Coverables
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage pattern attributes
The CoveragePattern attributes determine whether or not each relevant coverage is offered on a policy, and whether the user can accept (elect) the coverage or decline it. Business analysts collect the answers to these questions, and developers implement the pattern based on the subsequent requirements.
slides.notes:
Coverage pattern attributes
The CoveragePattern attributes determine whether or not each relevant coverage is offered on a policy, and whether the user can accept (elect) the coverage or decline it. Business analysts collect the answers to these questions, and developers implement the pattern based on the subsequent requirements.
slides.narration: In some scenarios, a single coverable might need to be linked to multiple coverage tables, especially when dealing with unique coverage patterns. However, Guidewire generally recommends using one coverage table per coverable unless there's a compelling reason to do otherwise. This approach simplifies management and ensures consistency, making it easier to maintain and extend the system.

slides.title: Exploring Coverage Categories in Personal Auto
slides.originalNotes:
Covered object
It is possible to associate more than one coverage table with a coverable. For example, this might be appropriate if some coverage patterns have unusual characteristics from all other coverages. You define one coverage table for each coverable. However, you can associate more than one coverage table with a coverable. For example, if some coverage patterns have characteristics that are different from all other coverages, you can define asecond coverage table. Be sure to include in the definition of the coverage table any values needed for all coverage patterns that can be used for the coverable.

Note: In general, Guidewire recommends that you use one coverage table for each coverable, unless there is a clear use case for a second coverage table.
slides.notes:
Covered object

slides.narration: Moving on to coverage categories, these are collections of related coverage patterns typically added to a policy as a group. For example, the Personal Auto Physical Damage Group encompasses several coverage patterns. By grouping them, PolicyCenter ensures that policies are comprehensive and consistent, reflecting the insurer's offerings effectively. This is also a critical point for developers to consider when configuring the UI and backend logic.

slides.title: Coverage Lookup Tables for Availability
slides.notes: Availability criteria for coverages are stored in lookup tables, which can be referenced by multiple coverages.
slides.narration: Coverages rely on lookup tables to determine their availability based on various criteria, such as state or underwriting company. These tables are referenced by multiple coverages and define the conditions under which a coverage can be offered. As a developer, you'll often interact with these tables to ensure that the correct availability logic is applied, aligning with business requirements.
slides.ocrText:
| PolicyCenter and coverage pattern outcome Gi

• PolicyCenter records selection of coverage in database

• PolicyCenter does not store information on an electable or suggested coverage
declined by user

• There is one database row for each coverage that exists on a policy

slides.title: Subclause Relationships in Advanced Product Designer
slides.notes: Subclause relationships allow for complex clause hierarchies, useful for grouping coverages, conditions, and exclusions.
slides.narration: The Advanced Product Designer in PolicyCenter offers robust tools for managing subclause relationships, allowing clauses like coverages, conditions, and exclusions to form complex hierarchies. These relationships are essential for reflecting real-world policy structures and enable insurers to offer nuanced product configurations. Understanding and implementing these relationships is key to building flexible and scalable insurance products.

slides.title: Managing Subclauses in PolicyCenter
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage categories — Personal Auto
The Personal Auto Physical Damage Group has four CoveragePatterns. The entirecoverage category is associatedwith the Personal Auto PolicyLinePattern.

While CoveragePatterns can be included individually in the user interface (PolicyCenter), coverages are usually added through a coverage category. A policy either has all the available coverages in the group or none of them. In addition to the example in the slide, another example is in the Business Owner's policy line. The "Location Coverages“ category contains the following
coverage patterns:
Outdoor signs
Windstorm/Hail
Outdoor Property
Personal Effects
Personal Property Off
Premises

slides.narration: Once you've created subclauses in the Advanced Product Designer, they can be imported into PolicyCenter for visualization and management. This integration ensures that product configurations are consistent and transparent. Developers can add or remove subclauses as needed, maintaining the integrity of the product's structure while adapting to evolving business needs.

slides.title: Summary and Next Steps
slides.notes: Recap the key points about coverages and introduce the next lesson on Coverage Terms.
slides.narration: We've covered a lot of ground in understanding coverages within PolicyCenter, from defining coverables to managing subclauses. These elements are crucial for ensuring that policies are comprehensive and align with business requirements. As we move forward, we'll dive into Coverage Terms, further exploring how specific terms are applied and managed within policies. This next lesson will build on the foundation we've established today, providing deeper insights into coverage management.
slides.ocrText:
| Recommended practices: coverage patterns

« When mapping coverage patterns to categories:
* Put coverages that will appear together into same category
« Use categories to separate coverages that appear automatically
« When rendering coverages on user interface:
* Put most commonly accepted coverages on "Included Coverages" tab

* Put less commonly accepted coverages on "Additional Coverages" tab

slides.title: Introducing the subclause relationship
slides.originalNotes:
Learner story for subclause replationships
Insurance companies often offer coverages as groups or families of coverages.

There is a feature in Advanced Product Designer which supports the subclause relationship for clauses, such as coverage, conditions, and exclusions.

For more information, please review the course for Advanced Product Designer
slides.notes:
Learner story for subclause replationships
Insurance companies often offer coverages as groups or families of coverages.

There is a feature in Advanced Product Designer which supports the subclause relationship for clauses, such as coverage, conditions, and exclusions.

For more information, please review the course for Advanced Product Designer

slides.title: Subclause relationships in Advanced Product Designer
slides.originalNotes:
Subclause relationships in Advanced Product Designer
You can create clauses with subclauses in a mind map.
A clause can have zero or one parent clause.
A clause can have multiple subclauses.
You can create multiple levels of subclauses.
The subclause and its parent must be of the same clause type. For example, anexclusion cannot be a subclause of a coverage.

After the mind map is imported into PolicyCenter, you can view the subclauses in the visualized product, You can also manage the subclause hierarchy by adding and removing subclauses.
slides.notes:

After the mind map is imported into PolicyCenter, you can view the subclauses in the visualized product, You can also manage the subclause hierarchy by adding and removing subclauses.

+ Remove a subclause
